security: This document contains information about CIA efforts to penetrate the USSR and interviews with CIA personnel, including details of their roles, assignments, and recollections of past events and operations. Disclosing specific details about these operations and personnel could compromise intelligence sources and methods, as well as potentially expose individuals associated with sensitive activities. The document details interviews related to 'Technical Aids Detachment' (TAD) in Frankfurt and an operation with JOHN PARKER and HARRY ROSITZKE of the SR (Soviet Russia) Division and flew to Berlin in 1952 in this connection. KARLOW explained the operation involved a planned attempt to steal the latest model MIG fighter plane and great preparation had been made but at the last minute the adventure was called off because of possible, political and diplomatic repercussions
summary: This document is a compilation of interviews conducted by the FBI in March 1963 pertaining to various individuals associated with the CIA, focusing on topics such as CIA efforts to penetrate the USSR and details about the Technical Aids Detachment (TAD) in Frankfurt, Germany.
summary_one_paragraph: This FBI document, dated March 5, 1963, consists of interviews related to a case file, and focuses on the CIA's efforts to penetrate the USSR, and it includes interviews with Joseph Burk, James Critchfield, William K. Harvey, Earl Allen Gold, Serge Peter Karlow, Mrs. Ferida Karlow, Mrs. Peter Karlow and Roland Ernest Dulin. The interviews cover subjects such as assignments within the CIA, travel in Europe, and recollections of various operations and personnel. The document reveals insights into the organization and activities of the CIA's Technical Aids Detachment (TAD) and discussions about potential recruitment of individuals for positions in Moscow.
title: Interview summaries related to William K. Harvey and CIA activities
